phrase.item: ButterPreparation
Ordinarily, we prepare butter this way: first we milk the livestock (cows, goats, sheep) in a pot or better yet in a jug (pitcher) or a milking bucket.
When there is a lot of milk, we boil it.
Next we pour it in a bucket or a pot.
Then we add a bit of buttermilk so that it turns.
Thus we obtain the kefir (curds/fermented milk?)
Butter, buttermilk. When the kefir (kurds/fermented milk?) is ready, we pour it in a churn.
It is equipped with a reel, a wicker circle, and a belt.
We churn for one to two hours.
If foam (froth) forms, we add hot water.
If no foam appears this means the kefir (kurds/fermented milk?) has reheated and so we add cold water.
Next we churn and when the butter appears at the surface and the buttermilk stays at the bottom, we remove this butter.
This is how we obtain (get) good butter.
If we take (gather) what is left, we get buttermilk.
Dried yogurt
Using the buttermilk we make different things: dried yogurt, tchka, and tchkakryt.
We make the dried yogurt like so: we pour the buttermilk in a pot and we cook it.
We cook it until it thickens.
Once it has thickened, we make balls out of it and we spread them on the roof or on rocks so that they dry.
These must be put in the och and in the querytov.
Tchka. We pour the buttermilk in a clean small sack.
All that is liquid leaves (escapes), the thick part stays.
This is how we obtain (get/make) tchka.
We take it, we add a bit of water, we dunk bread [in it] and we eat [it].
Tchkakryt.
We pour the buttermilk in a small sack.
When it had thickened we formed balls.
We scatter them on the rood and when they are dried we get tchkakryt.
We add them to food or we eat them with bread.
Lenditch.
We pour milk in a pot (cauldron).
It must be without water and if any cream has already formed at its surface, we don't take it.
Then we cook it.
We cook it so that it doesn't burn or stick to [the sides of] the pot (cauldron).
We cook it until it thickens.
Next we take it out and once it has cooled, we knead it in the shape of little galettes (cakes).
The lenditch must not dry in the sun.
Cheese
We pour milk in a pot (cauldron) and when it comes to a boil, we add buttermilk or tchka.
Next we cook [it].
All of the liquid evaporates, [only] the thick[ness] remains.
Then we envelop it in gauze and we press it, in order to extract all of the liquid.
Next we knead it in the form of little galettes (cakes) and we dry them in the sun so that they are hard and don't crumble.
Then we gather them and we eat them.
Ketakhin
it's buttermilk; sweetened buttermilk.
It turns and thickens on its own.
This is ketakhin.
We cook it in bread and we eat it.
Bread
Bread is considered an essential (staple) food for human life.
We make bread like so: we take (put) any flour: barley, millet or wheat in a container.
We dump it through a sieve and we sift it.
We obtain fine flour; large particles are left over
we give them to the livestock.
With the sifted flour and hot or warm water, we prepare the leaven (yeast?).
We let the leaven (yeast?) of this flour rest for twenty four hours.
It sours; this is the leaven (yeast?).
Then we mix it with the sifted flower and we obtain dough.
We let the dough rest for an hour or two so that it rises.
When it has risen we remove it with a iron hook and knead it into little galettes (cake shapes).
But beforehand we make a fire so that the hearth (oven) is burning [hot].
When the fire has burned we place the galettes up against the walls of the hearth (oven) with the help of a little felt cushion.
Once they have cooked in the hearth (oven) we take them out and we place them onto embeers so that their crust gets a golden color.
Before applying the galettes against the walls of the hearth (oven), we moisten them with water or buttermilk, or milk if there is any, so that they are [all] white and beautiful.
Ptok
We prepare the ptoks when there is a marriage, engagement, Ramadan and Kurban celebrations, and when we visit parents or a married girl (woman.)
For the ptok: we sift (separate) the pure wheat flour through a gauze or horsehair sieve.
Next we melt butter and we add it to the flour. Then we heat water, we salt it and we also add flour.
Then we knead the dough but we don't let it rise.
We take it in little quantities (little by little) and we make some [galettes.]
We poke them on top with a little feather brush (that we call pertchouk: large pigeon feathers, chicken feathers and wild pigeon feathers tied together)
Next we put the ptoks on a round mat of woven reeds, we heat the hearth (oven) properly and we apply them on the walls of the hearth by hand.
A little felt cushion is not necessary.
Once they are golden we remove them.
While removing them we count them: one batch of nine, two batches of nine..., nine batches of nine.
Aside from galettes, wheat flour is used to make the following other sorts of bread: quemotch, quemotchdouni and derkhtov.
Quemotch
We prepare the quemotch in the following way: we sift flour and we add leaven. (yeast?)
We don't give it to time to rise. (We don't let it rise.)
We put a bit of salt in the water and we knead the dough.
In the bread making receptacle there can be from five to ten or twenty kilos of flour.
Next we make a quemotch from all of the dough.
Then we make a fire in a way so that there isn't too much smoke and so that the flame isn't too wild.
We place this quemotch on the embers and when is cooked through (to perfection) we take it out.
We cook these sorts of quemotchs when there is no butter while on the road (traveling) or during Chogoun.
Quemotchdouni
We make the quemotchdouni in the following way: we melt butter and we mix it with wheat flour.
We add hot water and we knead the dough.
We heat a pan in advance so that it doesn't stick.
Then we place this dough on the pan and we put it over the fire and cover it with another pan.
When it begins to smell it's a sign that it's cooked.
So we remove it.
It [quemotchdouni] is devoid of ashes while ashes mix in with the quemotch.
We cook (make) quemotchdouni to give it (as a gift) to someone or as traveling provisions.
Derkhtov
We make derkhtovs in the following way: we sift the flour through a cloth.
We obtain a fine flour to which we add cold water.
Then we knead the dough.
When the dough is kneaded we take little pieces and with a rolling pin form them into crepe shapes for a broth.
Then with a little felt cushion we place them up against the walls of the hearth (oven).
We don't make them golden (wait until the're golden); we take them out as soon as they're cooked.
We make them for roukhnptek typically.
Sometimes we boil milk and we crumble them [up] in the milk, we call this food chirfetir.
We also cook derkhtovs for the "throwing of the pan" ritual.
Roukhnptek
We use roukhnpteks during celebrations: for a marriage, a housewaring party, a new acquisition.
We make the roukhnpteks in the following way: we put bits of butter and granulated sugar on top of derkhovs and we serve [them].
We place a roukhnptek in front of each person who comes.
Semnxetch
We prepare the malt in the following way: we take clean wheat and we wet it.
After some time it germinates.
When it has germinated, we dry it and next we grind it in the mill.
Thus the flour obtained is sweet.
We cook the galettes (little cakes) with a mix of this flour and regular sifted flour, this is how we get semnxetch.
And if we cook quemotchs we get semnquemotchs.
Chouchp I
If we mix malt with ice, and we put it in a pot over the fire and we cook it for four to five hours at a low heat, we get chouchp.
Chouchp is also sweet.
It's a good old Wakhan dish that has been preserved until today.
We prepare it for the chogoun, during sowing or when we just want some.
We put milk and butter on top.
Chouchp II
We pile up the kernels of apricot pits and we grind them [up].
We pour water in a pot and we throw in the ground kernels.
We remove the hard parts (bits) from the bottom of the pot and we grind them once more on a stone. We throw them back into the pot.
Next we transfer the water with a ladel and once again pour the water in the pot.
It's bitterness disappears.
Then we add flour, we knead the dough.
After the flour we add malt flour.
Next we light the fire in the hearth (oven).
We stir it with a wooden spoon.
The chouchp is cooked on very low heat.
We put it on in the morning and take it off at night.
We put it on the fire around nine in the morning and around nine at night we take it off of the fire.
Next we draw it out and once it has cooled we eat it in the morning.
We pour milk over it; we add butter and we eat [it].
Och (soup)
We prepare the och for a long time with two types of flour.
First we prepare it with leguminous flour, then with wheat flour.
There are two sorts of och: noodle [form] and crepe [form].
For the crepe och we only mix the dough, we stretch it out with a rolling pin and when the water comes to a boil we throw it in and we flip it with a spatula.
We use a stick with four (small) branches as a spatula.
It's used to flip the och and we call it ochkaw.
We prepare the other type of och in the following way: we knead the dough, we stretch it with a rolling pin and we cut it with a sort of steel knife: the ochbyr.
Then, when the water is boiling in the pot, we throw it [the cut dough] in.
We add salt, qeryt or buttermilk.
Next we eat it with wooden spoons.
We pass the spoon to one another, each person gives it to the next.
The wheat flour och is prepared a bit differently: we melt butter and we add onion and pepper, we prepare this och most often for sick people who have a fever or a cold.
We also make it into noodles.
Chirchoi
We make tea like so: we pour clean water in a teapot or a small pot and we put it over the fire.
We throw in a large quantity of tea: the stronger it is, the better, because tea intoxicates.
When the tea has boiled, we mix in creme fraiche and salt.
If there is butter we put some in the bowl at the same time as the tea.
We drink as much as we can.
We dunk bread in the tea and each person eats according to their appetite.
Bean Stew
We prepare the bean stew by cooking it for a very long time with water until it becomes amost as soft (mushy) as dough.
We add salted water or salt to it.
If we prepare pea stew, we cook it equally as long until it becomes liquid.
We also add salt to it.
We drink this infusion which is an indispensable remedy (medicine)
for those with intestinal worms.
We prepare bean stew only during during the sowing of legumes.
We also prepare it another way.
Once it is cooked, we remove the water then we put the pot back on the fire and we cook it without water.
Next we stir it and we get what we call pakhtik.
Batt
We begin by melting butter while stiring it.
For this we make a fire that isn't too strong.
Then we add a small bit of wheat flour.
Then we stir it so that it doesn't stick to the pot.
We heat up water and we add a bit so that it isn't too thick.
We add salt to the water and it becomes salty.
We only pour in a bit of this water so that it isn't too salty.
Then we stir.
The butter separates itself from the batt, then we spread it on bread and we eat [it].
And if the butter doesn't separate, it means that the batt wasn't successful and the taste is more like kotchi.
If it's milk that we pour in the pot, we bbtain (get) alvochir.
If we cook it with fatty meat we obtain (get) qelyabatt or tarbatt.
We make batt regularly but even more often during the arrivals and returns to the [summer] pastures, in this case it's zitchbatt.
We prepare the qelyabatt for festivities (celebrations) or funerals.
We make terbatt when we slaughter a sheep and it has a lot of fat. ‎‎If we want we can use this fat to fry.
It's an ancient dish from the pamirien territory (homeland) that has been preserved.
We also prepare it for a very dear friend or for a guest.
Dyne
Dyne is an ancient dish of our people.
We prepare it when we want or for the first time a child leaves the home, of a lamb or a kid (baby goat) and also when during the sowing of wheat.
We only cook wheat grains.
First we light the fire and we heat up a pan.
Then we pour in a little bit of grains, they grill and we stir them.
We cook them until they pop.
We also proceed in another way. We put salt in water and it becomes very salty and we sprinkle this salted water on the grrilled grains so that the dyne is salty.
Without salt we get mushy grains, but hard (crisp) ones with the salt.
We musn't eat the grilled grains one by one, only two by two, i.e. by pair.
We mustn't wat them one by one because one by one is odd (as in an odd number).
Querytov
There is another dish, it's querytov.
We prepare the querytov like so: we put queryt in hot water, it dissolves and the water becomes queryt flavored.
Next we melt butter and we add onion and wild onion to it.
If there is any, we add sugar and thus it becomes sweet.
Next we take hot bread and we crumble it up (inside); this is what we call querytov.
Leafy Vegetable
There are different kinds of this leavy vegetable.
We make xazg with pumpkin (squash), certain herbs, capers, sorrel.
First we cook all of this well, next we break up noodles by cutting them with a knife, then we melt butter and we mix wheat flour into it.
Next we add a bit of water, we stir and we let it cook.
Next we take it and, if there is any, we put butter on top and then we eat it with bread.
Choula
We prepare the choula like so: first we cook meat and when the meat is cooked we mix it with rice.
Then we put it over a soft fire (low heat) so that it puffs [up], like pilaf.
We only cook choula with meat broth.
Pest
We prepare the pest with wheat, peas, or barley.
First we brown (fry) the peas and barley like the wheat grains.
Then we grind them in the mill.
When it turns into flour we pour it in milk or water and we eat it.
If we mix it with butter, we get kepatch which is a very tasty dish.
If on top of that we add sugar it will be very sweet.
Chapik
First we knead the dough with flour.
We add water, salt, minced onion in flour and we make the dough.
Next we leave it and let it rise.
Then we light the fire and we place a flat stone on the hearth.
It heats up.
When it's nice and hot, we cover it with butter.
We put a coat of butter on this flat stone.
We place the dough on this.
Then we spread it [out]
We even it out
We flatten it.
When it is cooked we melt butter and sprinkle it on. Then we eat it with bread.
Tchimbir
When the apricot tree reaches maturity, the fruits fall on their own.
We call them "fallen by the wind"
We gather them and we spread them out in the sun.
When they have dried, we call them tchimbir.
We make compote (puree) and khechpai with dried apricots.
Sometimes we moisten them and we steam them with the pilaf.
Makyt
We pile up the kernels of apricot pits amd we grind them carefully.
An oil drips out.
Then we mix them with flour intodough and we cook it.
We only cook them only over smoke until they're halfway cooked. This is how we get (make) makyt.
We prepare it during Chogoun.
Khechpai, kotchi
There are two kinds of khechpai: water khechpai and oil (butter) khechpai. For the water khechpai we first brown flour and we pour it in water. When it's cooked it becomes liquid.
If it becomes thick you get kotchi.
If we make it with oil (butter) we get oil (butter) khechpai.
Milk Kotchi
We boil milk and we leave it in the pot for a while.
Then we add flour and we mix it.
Once it's cooked we add salt or sugar, whatever we find (have).
Then we take it off [the fire] and we add butter.
Next we take metal spoons and we eat [it].
Chirbrendj
We prepare the chirbrendj in the following way: we rince rice and we cook it with water in a pot.
When the grains have softened, there is only a bit of water left.
So we add milk.
When the chirbrendj is cooked and has thickened, we take it off [the fire] and we put it in a large bowl.
Once it has cooled we melt butter and we sprinkle it in.
But before that we put salt and sugar, if there is any, so that it's a bit sweeter.
Then we eat it on bread or with metal spoons.
Sbatz
We gather peas and we cook them.
When they are cooked we eat them.
This is sbatz and we only make it at the celebration of the pea harvest.
Kalklok
We put unshelled beans in hot ashes (coals).
When they are cooked, we eat them.
We also only prepare this during harvest time. (?)
Tchnir
We tie ears of barley or wheat together and we put them in hot ashes (coals).
Their grains (seeds) become tender, beautiful, and cooked.
Then we rub them between our palms, we clean them and we eat [them].
We also make this at the celebrations for the barley and wheat harvests.
